title: Astros respond to Sports Illustrated report alleging executive’s clubhouse blowup
text:
The incident occurred after Game 6 of the American League Championship Series.

According to the SI report, Astros assistant general manager Brandon Taubman repeatedly yelled supportive comments about closer Roberto Osuna to a group of three female reporters in the Houston clubhouse. Osuna was acquired by the Astros in 2018 while serving a 75-game suspension under Major League Baseball’s domestic violence policy.

AD

Taubman reportedly turned to the reporters, one of whom was reportedly wearing a purple domestic violence awareness bracelet, and repeatedly yelled: “Thank God we got Osuna! I’m so f------ glad we got Osuna!” The reliever had blown a save opportunity in the ninth inning of the decisive game against the New York Yankees before Houston’s José Altuve hit a two-run home run in the bottom of the frame to set up a World Series matchup with the Washington Nationals.

AD

Sports Illustrated reported that Taubman’s outburst “was offensive and frightening enough that another Houston staffer apologized.”

Though the report was later confirmed by multiple other reporters who were in the clubhouse, the Astros issued a statement Monday night describing the Sports Illustrated story as “misleading and completely irresponsible.” The Astros said a Houston player was “being asked questions about a difficult outing,” and their “executive was supporting the player during a difficult time.”

AD

“His comments had everything to do with the game situation that just occurred and nothing else — they were also not directed toward any specific reporters,” the Astros said in the statement. “We are extremely disappointed in Sports Illustrated’s attempt to fabricate a story where one does not exist.”

AD

After the Astros released their statement, the Houston Chronicle reported that two of its reporters were able to confirm the claims made by Sports Illustrated. A reporter for Yahoo Sports also said she could provide confirmation.

The Chronicle cited two eyewitnesses in reporting that Taubman was “holding a cigar and standing with two or three other men when he yelled his comments,” and that the group of female reporters was “approximately eight feet away and one was visibly shaken by the comment.” The Chronicle also reported there were no players in the area and no interviews were being conducted at the time, disputing the team’s claim.

AD

The Astros called this @stephapstein report misleading. It is not. I was there. Saw it. And I should’ve said something sooner.



https://t.co/aE4WEgUJox — Hunter Atkins (@HunterAtkins35) October 22, 2019

Three eyewitnesses —

including two Chronicle reporters — confirm @stephapstein's reporting of Brandon Taubman's conduct in the Astros' ALCS clinching clubhouse - https://t.co/ukRn8TQcFY — Chandler Rome (@Chandler_Rome) October 22, 2019

Osuna, 24, was traded to the Astros from the Toronto Blue Jays in July 2018, as he was nearing the end of a suspension levied in May of that year. Houston was viewed at the time as having filled a need for a closer by acquiring the talented pitcher, a 2017 all-star, at a relative discount because of his notoriety.

AD

Osuna was charged in May 2018 with assault in a case allegedly involving the mother of his young child. Prosecutors eventually dropped the charge when she communicated to them that she would not travel from Mexico to Canada to testify against him. The case ended with Osuna signing a peace bond, with no admission of guilt, plus an agreement by him to stay away from the woman and continue counseling.

“The Astros remain committed to increase our support regarding the issues of domestic violence and abuse of any kind,” the team said in a statement at the time.

description: The report accused assistant general manager Brandon Taubman of deliberately yelling supportive comments about reliever Roberto Osuna to a group of female reporters. The team acquired Osuna in 2018 while he was serving a 75-game suspension under MLB’s domestic violence policy.
